exploration_path.sentence_content: I started by getting a feel for what an ‘attainable’ home looks like across London, just a broad scan of where the average and median prices sit.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) Choropleth — median housing price by borough; (b) Ranked bar chart — borough price with London median band; (c) Band filters — below-median, near-median toggles

exploration_path.sentence_content: Price alone felt blunt, so I reframed it as value: how much access to schools and libraries you effectively get per pound of purchase price.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) KPI card — Value-per-Service Index = (schools/10k + libraries/10k) ÷ price; (b) Scatter — value index vs price (points=boroughs, color=price band); (c) Shortlist panel — pin top value boroughs within selected bands

exploration_path.sentence_content: Before I lock anything in, I layered the ethnicity diversity and country-of-birth mix onto that shortlist to see how fit lines up with value.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) Leaderboard — ethnicity diversity (entropy); (b) Gauge — country_of_birth variety score; (c) Overlay — diversity badges on shortlisted boroughs

exploration_path.sentence_content: I nudged up the boroughs that are already high-diversity and still inside the attainable price bands.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) Filter — top diversity quartile ∧ (below/near-median price); (b) Chip list — promoted candidates; (c) Note — assumption card ‘diversity ↔ sustained desirability’

exploration_path.sentence_content: Then I tested co-location: do these same places hold up on schools and libraries, or is it a single bright spot hiding the rest?
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) Matrix heatmap — candidates × {diversity, schools quartile pass, library evenness pass}; (b) Drill-through — ward-level detail for any ‘fail’ cells

exploration_path.sentence_content: On the schools side, ward views looked solid overall, though a couple of borders felt brittle if catchment lines shift.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) Small multiples — schools per 10k by ward (within candidate borough); (b) Overlay — catchment boundary reference; (c) Stability badge — proportion of wards in top quartile

exploration_path.sentence_content: I checked that access isn’t just one shiny central branch, an even spread across neighborhoods matters for the day-to-day.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) Bar chart — branches per ward; (b) Evenness index card (e.g., Gini-style); (c) Pin map — library locations with ward overlays

exploration_path.sentence_content: I started with top-quartile schools and strong library coverage, then keep the ones that still sit in the attainable bands.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) Dual filter — schools top quartile ∧ libraries per 10k above median; (b) Overlay — price-band shading; (c) Candidate table — survivors with spark bars for both metrics

exploration_path.sentence_content: That surfaced a borough with excellent schools and libraries but noticeably lower diversity than peers, which is great for education, less obvious for cultural breadth.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) Side-by-side tiles — schools KPI, libraries KPI, diversity indices; (b) Comparative strip — candidate vs London median

exploration_path.sentence_content: The result seems to be conditional: a strong pick for education-first buyers, but I’d caveat it for anyone prioritizing community breadth.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) Persona toggles — ‘education-first’ vs ‘community-first’; (b) Note card — conditional recommendation rationale

exploration_path.sentence_content: I looked inside that borough to see if there’s a middle path, some wards might balance stronger diversity with the same service strengths.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) Ward-level heatmaps — ethnicity entropy & country_of_birth variety; (b) Small multiples — ward schools KPIs; (c) Overlay — libraries-per-ward coverage

exploration_path.sentence_content: That micro-fit helped—two wards blended better diversity without losing school/library advantages, so I kept the borough with ward-level guidance for buyers who want education first but still some variety.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (a) ‘Target wards’ card — list with evidence links; (b) Save to plan — attach ward notes to borough

data_story.data_story_sentence: We began by establishing an attainable purchase band using borough median housing prices, isolating below- and near-median segments.
We defined a value-per-service index—(schools per 10k + libraries per 10k) divided by price—and shortlisted boroughs with high indices within that band.
To reflect multi-decade neighborhood fit, we overlaid ethnicity diversity (entropy) and country-of-birth variety on the same shortlist.
Within the price band, high-diversity boroughs were prioritized as candidates for long-term resilience.
Co-location checks verified that these candidates also met top-quartile school access and exhibited strong library coverage.
Ward-level small multiples showed school access was broadly distributed across catchments, indicating stability rather than a single outlier ward.
Library evenness metrics—branches per ward with an evenness index—confirmed access was neighborhood-wide, not hub-concentrated.
A parallel services-first slice surfaced a borough with excellent schools and libraries yet lower diversity than peers, motivating a conditional, education-first recommendation.
